p: The characteristics of the geochemical proxies not only indicate the degree of chemical weathering in the lake catchment, but can also indicate the conditions of climate evolution and the changes in the depositional environment [ 26â€“ 28]. Therefore, the geochemical elements of lacustrine deposits can be used to study climate change [ 29, 30]. The values of (CaO+K 2O+Na 2O)/Al 2O 3, the index of mineral chemical differentiation (ICV) and the chemical weathering index (CIA) can represent paleoclimatic proxies of the chemical weathering intensity and effective moisture [ 31, 32].
